translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
First Section🔽The Discussion of Relinquishment
The Discussion of the Non-Removal of the Thread
“Does the worldling relinquish greed and hate?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Accantaṁ jahati, anavasesaṁ jahati, appaṭisandhiyaṁ jahati, samūlaṁ jahati, sataṇhaṁ🔽jahati, sānusayaṁ jahati, ariyena ñāṇena jahati, ariyena maggena jahati, akuppaṁ
analyzed: āmantā  accantam jahati anavasesam jahati appaṭisandhiyam jahati sa mūlam jahati  jahati sa anusayam jahati ariyena ñāṇena jahati ariyena maggena jahati akuppa
translated: “Certainly.”

analyzed: paṭivijjhantaḥ jahati anāgāmi phalam sacchikarontaḥ jahati iti
translated: “Does he relinquish them utterly, completely, so that they do not lead to renewed existence? Does he relinquish them with the noble knowledge of the fruit of non-returning? Does he relinquish them by penetrating the imperturbable? Does he relinquish them by realizing the fruit of non-returning?”
“That cannot be said.”

analyzed: vikkhambheti puthujjanaḥ kāma rāga byāpāda nti
translated: “Does the worldling suppress greed and hate?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Accantaṁ vikkhambheti, anavasesaṁ vikkhambheti, appaṭisandhiyaṁ vikkhambheti, samūlaṁ
analyzed: āmantā  accantam vikkhambheti anavasesam vikkhambheti appaṭisandhiyam vikkhambheti sa mūla
translated: “Certainly.”

original: vikkhambheti, sataṇhaṁ vikkhambheti, sānusayaṁ vikkhambheti, ariyena ñāṇena vikkhambheti,
analyzed: vikkhambheti sa taṇham vikkhambheti sa anusayam vikkhambheti ariyena ñāṇena vikkhambheti
translated: “Does he suppress them utterly, completely, so that they do not lead to renewed existence? Does he suppress them with the noble knowledge of the fruit of non-returning? Does he suppress them by penetrating the imperturbable?

original: ariyena maggena vikkhambheti, akuppaṁ paṭivijjhanto vikkhambheti, anāgāmiphalaṁ sacchikaronto vikkhambhetīti?
analyzed: ariyena maggena vikkhambheti akuppam paṭivijjhantaḥ vikkhambheti anāgāmi phalam sacchikarontaḥ vikkhambheti iti
translated: does he suppress it by means of the noble path? Does he suppress it by penetrating to the imperturbable? Does he suppress it by realizing the fruit of non-return?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: Jahati anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca accantaṁ jahati, anavasesaṁ jahati …pe…
analyzed: jahati anāgāmi phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāma rāga byāpāda so ca accantam jahati anavasesam jahati pe
translated: “A person who is practicing for the realization of the fruit of non-return abandons sensual desire and ill will, and he completely abandons them, he abandons them without remainder. …
Does he abandon them by realizing the fruit of non-return?”
“Yes.”

original: Jahati puthujjano kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca accantaṁ jahati, anavasesaṁ jahati …pe…
analyzed: jahati puthujjanaḥ kāma rāga byāpāda saḥ ca accantam jahati anavasesam jahati pe
translated: “A normal person abandons sensual desire and ill will, and he completely abandons them, he abandons them without remainder. …
Does he abandon them by realizing the fruit of non-return?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: Vikkhambheti anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca accantaṁ vikkhambheti, anavasesaṁ vikkhambheti …pe…
analyzed: vikkhambheti anāgāmi phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāma rāga byāpāda so ca accantam vikkhambheti anavasesam vikkhambheti pe
translated: “A person who is practicing for the realization of the fruit of non-return suppresses sensual desire and ill will, and he completely suppresses them, he suppresses them without remainder. …
Does he suppress them by realizing the fruit of non-return?”
“Yes.”🔽“A normal person suppresses sensual desire and ill will, and he completely suppresses them, he suppresses them without remainder. …

original: Vikkhambheti puthujjano kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca accantaṁ vikkhambheti, anavasesaṁ vikkhambheti …pe…
analyzed: vikkhambheti puthujjanaḥ kāma rāga byāpāda saḥ ca accantam vikkhambheti anavasesam vikkhambheti pe
translated: Does the worldling suppress sense-desire and ill-will, and does he completely suppress them, does he suppress them without remainder? …
Does he who realizes the fruit of non-returning suppress …?
You should not say so.

original: Jahati puthujjano kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca na accantaṁ jahati, na anavasesaṁ jahati …pe…
analyzed: jahati puthujjanaḥ kāma rāga byāpāda saḥ ca na accantam jahati na anavasesam jahati pe
translated: Does the worldling abandon sense-desire and ill-will, and does he not completely abandon them, does he not abandon them without remainder? …

analyzed: na anāgāmi phalam sacchikarontaḥ jahati iti
translated: Does he who realizes the fruit of non-returning abandon …?

original: Āmantā.🔽Jahati anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca na accantaṁ jahati …pe…
analyzed: āmantā  jahati anāgāmi phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāma rāga byāpāda so ca na accantam jahati pe
translated: You should not say so.🔽Does a person who is practising for the realization of the fruit of non-returning abandon sense-desire and ill-will, and does he not completely abandon them, does he not abandon them without remainder?

analyzed: na anāgāmi phalam sacchikarontaḥ jahati iti
translated: Does he who realizes the fruit of non-returning abandon …?

original: Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….🔽Vikkhambheti puthujjano kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca na accantaṁ vikkhambheti, na anavasesaṁ vikkhambheti …pe…
analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  vikkhambheti puthujjanaḥ kāma rāga byāpāda so ca na accantam vikkhambheti na anavasesam vikkhambheti pe
translated: You should not say so.🔽Does the worldling suppress sense-desire and ill-will, and does he not completely suppress them, does he not suppress them without remainder? …

analyzed: na anāgāmi phalam sacchikarontaḥ vikkhambheti iti
translated: Does he who realizes the fruit of non-returning suppress …?
You should not say so.

original: Vikkhambheti anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca na accantaṁ vikkhambheti, na anavasesaṁ vikkhambheti …pe…
analyzed: vikkhambheti anāgāmi phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo kāma rāga byāpāda so ca na accantam vikkhambheti na anavasesam vikkhambheti pe
translated: Does a person who is practising for the realization of the fruit of non-returner suppress sense-desire and ill-will, and does he not completely suppress them, does he not suppress them without remainder? …

analyzed: na anāgāmi phalam sacchikarontaḥ vikkhambheti iti
translated: Does he suppress them when he realizes the fruit of non-returner?”
“That can’t be said.”
“Does an ordinary person abandon sense-desire and ill-will?”
“Yes.”
“By what path?”
“By the path of the form-world.”

original: Rūpāvacaro maggo niyyāniko khayagāmī bodhagāmī apacayagāmī anāsavo asaṁyojaniyo aganthaniyo anoghaniyo ayoganiyo anīvaraṇiyo aparāmaṭṭho anupādāniyo asaṅkilesiyoti?
analyzed: rūpāvacaraḥ maggaḥ niyyānikaḥ khaya gāmī bodha gāmī apacaya gāmī anāsavaḥ a sayojaniyaḥ a gantha niyaḥ an ogha niyaḥ a yoga niyaḥ anīvaraṇiyaḥ a parāmaṭṭhaḥ an upādāniyaḥ a saṅkilesiyaḥ ti
translated: “Is the path of the form-world the escape, leading to the destruction of, leading to the deathless, leading to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to the complete destruction of suffering, to the uncontaminated, to independence from others, to not being bound up, to not being attached, to not being obstructed, to not being clung to, to not being grasped at, to non-defilement?”
“That can’t be said.”

original: Nanu rūpāvacaro maggo aniyyāniko na khayagāmī na bodhagāmī na apacayagāmī sāsavo saṁyojaniyo …pe… saṅkilesiyoti?
analyzed: nanu rūpāvacaraḥ maggaḥ aniyyānikaḥ na khaya gāmī na bodha gāmī na apacaya gāmī sa āsavaḥ sayojaniyaḥ pe saṅkilesiyaḥ ti
translated: “Isn’t the path of the form-world not the escape, not leading to the destruction of, not leading to the deathless, not leading to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to the complete destruction of suffering, to the uncontaminated, to independence from others, to not being bound up, to not being attached, to not being obstructed, to not being clung to, to not being grasped at, to non-defilement?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci rūpāvacaro maggo aniyyāniko na khayagāmī …pe…
analyzed: āmantā  hañci rūpāvacaraḥ maggaḥ aniyyānikaḥ na khaya gāmī pe
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Well then, you can’t say:🔽‘The path of the form-world is not the escape, not leading to the destruction of …

original: saṅkilesiyo, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: saṅkilesiyaḥ no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: to non-defilement.’

analyzed: jahati puthujjanaḥ rūpāvacarena maggena kāma rāga byāpāda nti
translated: “The worldling abandons sensual desire and ill will by means of the path of the fine-material sphere.”

original: Jahati anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo anāgāmimaggena kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca maggo niyyāniko khayagāmī bodhagāmī apacayagāmī anāsavo …pe…
analyzed: jahati anāgāmi phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannaḥ puggalaḥ anāgāmi maggena kāma rāga byāpāda so ca maggaḥ niyyānikaḥ khaya gāmī bodha gāmī apacaya gāmī anāsavaḥ pe
translated: “The person who is practising for the realization of the fruit of non-return abandons sensual desire and ill will by means of the path of non-return, and that path is leading out, leading to the destruction , leading to knowledge , leading to peace , to direct knowledge , to enlightenment , to Nibbana.”
… is stainless?”
“Yes.”

original: Jahati puthujjano rūpāvacarena maggena kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca maggo niyyāniko khayagāmī bodhagāmī apacayagāmī anāsavo …pe…
analyzed: jahati puthujjanaḥ rūpāvacarena maggena kāma rāga byāpāda saḥ ca maggaḥ niyyānikaḥ khaya gāmī bodha gāmī apacaya gāmī anāsavaḥ pe
translated: “The worldling abandons sensual desire and ill will by means of the path of the fine-material sphere, and that path is leading out, leading to the destruction , leading to knowledge , leading to peace , to direct knowledge , to enlightenment , to Nibbana.”🔽… is stainless?”

analyzed: a saṅkilesiyaḥ ti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: ‘Not subject to defilement’?🔽… ‘Not subject to defilement’?”

original: Jahati puthujjano rūpāvacarena maggena kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca maggo aniyyāniko na khayagāmī na bodhagāmī na apacayagāmī sāsavo …pe…
analyzed: jahati puthujjanaḥ rūpāvacarena maggena kāma rāga byāpāda so ca maggaḥ aniyyānikaḥ na khaya gāmī na bodha gāmī na apacaya gāmī sa āsavaḥ pe
translated: “The worldling abandons sensual desire and ill will by means of the path of the fine-material sphere, and that path is not leading out, not leading to the destruction , not leading to knowledge , not leading to peace , not to direct knowledge , not to enlightenment , not to Nibbana.”
… is defiled?”

original: Jahati anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno puggalo anāgāmimaggena kāmarāgabyāpādaṁ, so ca maggo aniyyāniko na khayagāmī na bodhagāmī na apacayagāmī sāsavo …pe…
analyzed: jahati anāgāmi phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannaḥ puggalaḥ anāgāmi maggena kāma rāga byāpāda so ca maggaḥ aniyyānikaḥ na khaya gāmī na bodha gāmī na apacaya gāmī sa āsavaḥ pe
translated: A person who is practising for the realization of the fruit of non-return abandons sensual desire and ill will by the path of non-return. And that path is not leading out, not leading to freedom from bondage, not leading to enlightenment, not leading to peace, not leading to direct knowledge, not leading to self-awakening, not leading to Nibbāna, but it is connected with the taints, related to the taints, reckoned as subject to the taints.

“The person who is practicing for the realization of the fruit of non-return abandons sensual desire and ill will by the non-return path. And that path is not leading to dispassion, not leading to freedom from bondage, not leading to complete awakening, not leading to Nibbāna, but is subject to birth, subject to old age, subject to death, subject to sorrow, subject to lamentation, subject to despair, and subject to defilement?”
“No, friend.”

original: Puthujjano kāmesu vītarāgo saha dhammābhisamayā anāgāmiphale saṇṭhātīti?
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ kāmesu vīta rāgaḥ saha dhamma abhisamayā anāgāmi phale saṇṭhāti iti
translated: “The worldling, being free from lust for sensual pleasures, is established in the fruit of non-return at the time of the breakthrough to the Dhamma?”
“Yes.”
“Is he established in arahatship?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: Puthujjano kāmesu vītarāgo saha dhammābhisamayā anāgāmiphale saṇṭhātīti?
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ kāmesu vīta rāgaḥ saha dhamma abhisamayā anāgāmi phale saṇṭhāti iti
translated: “The worldling, being free from lust for sensual pleasures, is established in the fruit of non-return at the time of the breakthrough to the Dhamma?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: apubbam acarimam tayaḥ magge bhāveti iti
translated: “Does he develop the three paths without having developed them before, and for the first time he makes them habitual?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: apubbam acarimam tayaḥ magge bhāveti iti
translated: “Does he develop the three paths without having developed them before, and for the first time he makes them habitual?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: apubbam acarimam tīṇi sāmañña phalāni sacchikaroti iti
translated: “Does he realize the three fruits of asceticism without having realized them before, and for the first time he makes them his very own?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the abandoning of lust, the abandoning of hatred, the abandoning of delusion?

analyzed: apubbam acarimam tīṇi sāmañña phalāni sacchikaroti iti
translated: “Does he realize the three fruits of asceticism without having realized them before, and for the first time he makes them his very own?”
“Yes.”

original: Tiṇṇaṁ phassānaṁ tissannaṁ vedanānaṁ tissannaṁ saññānaṁ tissannaṁ cetanānaṁ tiṇṇaṁ🔽cittānaṁ tissannaṁ saddhānaṁ tiṇṇaṁ vīriyānaṁ tissannaṁ satīnaṁ tiṇṇaṁ samādhīnaṁ
analyzed: tiṇṇam phassānam tissannam vedanānam tissannam saññānam tissannam cetanānam tiṇṇam  cittānam tissannam saddhānam tiṇṇam vīriyānam tissannam satīnam tiṇṇam samādhīnam
translated: Is there a meeting together of three contacts, three feelings, three perceptions, three intentions, three🔽consciousnesses, three faiths, three energies, three mindfulnesses, three concentrations,
three understandings?
You say “No.” …

original: Puthujjano kāmesu vītarāgo saha dhammābhisamayā anāgāmiphale saṇṭhātīti?
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ kāmesu vīta rāgaḥ saha dhamma abhisamayā anāgāmi phale saṇṭhāti iti
translated: Does an ordinary person, free from passion for sensual desires, reach the fruit of non-return at the same time as the penetration of the Dhamma?
“Yes.”
“By the path of stream-entry?”
You say “No.” …
“By the path of once-return?”
You say “No.” …
“By which path?”
“By the path of non-return.”

analyzed: anāgāmi maggena sakkāya diṭṭhim vicikiccham sīlabbata parāmāsam jahati iti
translated: “By the path of non-return does one abandon personality view, doubt, and grasping at rules and observances?”
You say “No.” …
The Discussion of the Sutta

analyzed: anāgāmi maggena sakkāya diṭṭhim vicikiccham sīlabbata parāmāsam jahati iti
translated: “By the path of non-return does one abandon personality view, doubt, and grasping at rules and observances?”
“Yes.”

original: Nanu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānā sotāpattiphalaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatāti?
analyzed: nanu tiṇṇam sayojanānam pahānā sotāpatti phalam vuttam bhagavatā iti
translated: “Now, is it said by the Blessed One that the fruit of stream-entry is for the abandoning of the three fetters?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ pahānā sotāpattiphalaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci tiṇṇam sayojanānam pahānā sotāpatti phalam vuttam bhagavatā no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Now, the fruit of stream-entry has been stated by the Blessed One to be for the purpose of abandoning the three fetters. But it would not be proper to say:🔽

analyzed: anāgāmi maggena sakkāya diṭṭhim vicikiccham sīlabbata parāmāsam jahati iti
translated: “The fruit of stream-entry is stated by the Blessed One to be for the purpose of abandoning the three fetters. But it is not proper to say that one abandons the fetter of personality view, the fetter of doubt, and the fetter of adherence to rules and observances through the path of non-return.”

original: Anāgāmimaggena oḷārikaṁ kāmarāgaṁ oḷārikaṁ byāpādaṁ jahatīti?
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena oḷārikam kāma rāgam oḷārikam byāpādam jahati iti
translated: “One abandons gross sensual desire and gross ill will through the path of non-return?”
“It is not proper to say that …

original: Anāgāmimaggena oḷārikaṁ kāmarāgaṁ oḷārikaṁ byāpādaṁ jahatīti?
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena oḷārikam kāma rāgam oḷārikam byāpādam jahati iti
translated: “One abandons gross sensual desire and gross ill will through the path of non-return?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Nanu kāmarāgabyāpādānaṁ tanubhāvā sakadāgāmiphalaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatāti?
analyzed: āmantā  nanu kāma rāga byāpādānam tanu bhāvā sakadāgāmi phalam vuttam bhagavatā iti
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Now, the fruit of once-returning is stated by the Blessed One to be for the purpose of weakening sensual desire and ill will.”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci kāmarāgabyāpādānaṁ tanubhāvā sakadāgāmiphalaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci kāma rāga byāpādānam tanu bhāvā sakadāgāmi phalam vuttam bhagavatā no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”

analyzed: anāgāmi maggena oḷārikam kāma rāgam oḷārikam byāpādam jahati iti
translated: “The fruit of once-returning is stated by the Blessed One to be for the purpose of weakening sensual desire and ill will. But it is not proper to say that one abandons gross sensual desire and gross ill will through the path of non-return.”

original: Puthujjano kāmesu vītarāgo saha dhammābhisamayā anāgāmiphale saṇṭhātīti?
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ kāmesu vīta rāgaḥ saha dhamma abhisamayā anāgāmi phale saṇṭhāti iti
translated: “Does a worldling, being free from lust for sensual pleasures, reach the fruit of non-returning at the same time as the penetration of the dhammas?”
“Yes.”

original: Ye keci dhammaṁ abhisamenti, sabbe te saha dhammābhisamayā anāgāmiphale saṇṭhahantīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….
analyzed: ye keci dhammam abhisamenti sabbe te saha dhamma abhisamayā anāgāmi phale saṇṭhahanti iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe
translated: “All who realize the Dhamma are established in the fruit of non-return right with the realization of the Dhamma?”🔽“No, friend.”
“Then it should not be said that
‘The worldling abandons sensual desire and ill will.’
“Yes, friend.”

analyzed: nanu vuttam bhagavatā  ahesum te atītase
translated: “But has it not been said by the Blessed One:
‘In the past there were six teachers
Renowned, free from defilements, full of compassion,🔽Who had gone beyond the fetter of sensual pleasure.
Having abandoned sensual desire,
they went to the Brahma-world.
They had many hundreds of disciples,
Renowned, free from defilements, full of compassion,🔽Who had gone beyond the fetter of sensual pleasure.
Having abandoned sensual desire,

analyzed: brahma loka upagāḥ ahu iti  atthā iva suttanto ti
translated: they went to the Brahma-world.’
“Yes, friend.”
“Then it should be said that the worldling abandons sensual desire and ill will.”
“But is it said that the worldling abandons sensual desire and ill will?”
“Yes, friend.”
“But has it not been said by the Blessed One:

original: “so hi nāma, bhikkhave, sunetto satthā evaṁ dīghāyuko samāno evaṁ ciraṭṭhitiko aparimutto
analyzed: saḥ hi nāma bhikkhave su nettaḥ satthā evam dīgha āyukaḥ samānaḥ evam cira ṭṭhitikaḥ a parimuttaḥ
translated: ‘Bhikkhus, that teacher Sunetta, who had such a long life-span, who lived for so long, was not released from birth, aging, and death; from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair; he was not released from suffering, I say.

original: ahosi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi aparimutto dukkhasmāti vadāmi.
analyzed: ahosi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi a parimuttaḥ dukkhasma ati vadāmi
translated: He was not freed from birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. He was not freed, I tell you, from suffering and stress.
And why is that?
Because of not awakening to and penetrating four things.
What four?🔽Noble virtue, noble concentration, noble wisdom, and noble freedom.

original: Ariyassa sīlassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā, ariyassa samādhissa, ariyāya paññāya, ariyāya vimuttiyā ananubodhā appaṭivedhā.🔽Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ sīlaṁ anubuddhaṁ paṭividdhaṁ, ariyo samādhi anubuddho
analyzed: ariyassa sīlassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā ariyassa samādhissa ariyāya paññāya ariyāya vimuttiyāḥ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā  bhikkhave ariyam sīlam anubuddham paṭividdha ariyaḥ samādhi anubuddhaḥ
translated: But, bhikkhus, this noble virtue has been awakened to and penetrated,

original: paṭividdho, ariyā paññā anubuddhā paṭividdhā, ariyā vimutti anubuddhā paṭividdhā,
analyzed: paṭividdhaḥ ariyā paññā anubuddhā paṭividdhā ariyā vimutti anubuddhā paṭividdhā
translated: this noble concentration has been awakened to and penetrated, this noble wisdom has been awakened to and penetrated, and this noble freedom has been awakened to and penetrated.

original: ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, khīṇā bhavanetti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
analyzed: ucchinnā bhava taṇhā khīṇā bhava netti natthi dāni punabbhavaḥ ti
translated: Craving for existence has been cut off; the conduit to existence has been destroyed; now there is no continuation of existence.”
“Virtue, concentration, and wisdom,
and the unsurpassed freedom,
these things have been awakened to
by the illustrious Gotama.
Thus the Buddha, having directly known,
proclaimed this to the bhikkhus:
The Teacher, the maker of an end to suffering,
He has passed away, with vision.”
Is there a sutta that supports this?
“There is.”
“Well then, you shouldn’t say that
an ordinary disciple gives up sensual desire, ill will, and confusion.”
The discussion of giving up is finished.
